facts: Every living thing is made of cells, and some organisms are just one cell while humans have trillions.
DNA is like a set of instructions inside cells that helps determine traits such as eye color and how the body builds proteins.
Plants make their own food through photosynthesis, using sunlight to turn water and carbon dioxide into sugar and oxygen.
Your immune system uses special white blood cells to recognize germs and help protect you from getting sick.
Bacteria are everywhere, and many are helpful because they aid digestion and recycle nutrients in nature.
Ecosystems stay balanced through food chains, where energy moves from producers like plants to consumers like animals.
Some animals, like salamanders and starfish, can regrow lost body parts, which helps scientists study healing and development.
sources_hint: Check middle-school biology textbooks and reputable science sites like Britannica School, NASA (for photosynthesis basics), and NIH (for immune system overviews).
